div1.p: Consulat Général De L'État Indépendant Du Congo, Baltimore.
Memorandum on Clarence Rice Slocum, American Consul General to the Congo Free State.

He is the youngest of the late General Henry Warner Slocum, about 35 years old, married (his wife is, I think, of Swedish descent) and is said to be a manly, straightforward fellow, absolutely honest and fearless. I have just been talking about him with a friend of mine who was an old comrade of the General's and who knows all of the family very well. The General graduated at the United States Military Academy at West Point, left the army to practice law, but returned to the army on the outbreak of the Civil War in which he served with distinction. He afterwards was elected to Congress as a Democrat (about 1868 or 1870) and served in Congress several terms.

The General and his family lived in Brooklyn, N.Y., and went to the Congregational Church there but do not seem to have had any fanatical tendencies. Bridgman used to attend the same church and he is going to get me some additional information in a day or two.

Clarence Rice Slocum was appointed Consul at Warsaw in 1903 and transferred as Consul to Weimar March 8th 1905 I do not think he was engaged in any profession before that time, but, having inherited a rather large fortune from his father, went into several enterprises in which he is supposed to have lost money. He has a brother who is a stock-broker in New York, Henry W. Slocum; and a sister married to Kingsbury of the United States Army who has been living in Washington. She is now on a visit to her brother at Weimar, having sailed a week ago.

I will enquire more about him from Mr. Carr, Chief of the Consular Bureau of the Department of State, and when the Senator gets back to Washington (Wednesday or Thursday) I hope to get also a confidential report from "an authoritative source".
As Slocum and I have a number of mutual friends I shall try to arrange to met him on a friendly basis while in Europe next month.
